text:
(24) I will create an article + video on this!

If someone knows an editor who can help, please let me know :)

(23) Read this with an open mind if you want to learn <3

üßô‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

(22) Drop a retweet on the original tweet to share if you are already in NFTs and agree with what is said here.

Artists finally have a way to change the concept of "artists are starving"

A way for people to truly monetise their work.

Also, keep in mind, NFTs aren't just art.

(21) This was a long thread and I can nit-pick on other things if I wanted to but you will see many more tweets like this w/ false information.

If you are a bystander, read information from both sides, because people will always hate new things.

(20) 10 *(carried on):

As said above, I was an artist before, now I am also someone who writes about NFTs / a collector.

It's called promotion and sharing, this new thing that you may have seen on the news.

Not "recruiting", don't take it the wrong way.

(19) 10:

"Recruiting" ~ everyone is free to join the platform. No one is forcing you to, no one has a gun to your head telling you to make Crypto Art.

It's mostly artists sharing with their friends... the new way to monetise their work so they can live off art.

(18) 9:

The 'buy-in' here is taken out of context again. Who would have thought!

Coming back to this point, on most platforms, you have to pay an ETH gas fee to "mint" your artwork.

However, some platforms don't even require you to pay a fee! Did no one mention that? https://t.co/uhD0fpfn60

(17) 8 *(carried on):

You believe what you want. Why do you have to believe someone else? No one is telling you to believe them.

The blame shouldn't be placed on someone else because no one is forcing one-another, it is of your own accord.

(16) 8:

You aren't promised anything. If someone says that to you, then that isn't the "NFT" market. That is one individual person talking to you.

It is advertised everywhere... but that is for ANYTHING in the world. Someone will relay wrong information to you.

(15) 7:

Just information in the wrong context again. This doesn't have to be done on a platform where you face the fee.

It can all be done OTC!

Platforms aren't taking advantage of this, the % includes royalties to the original creator, so it's not as big as you think it is.

(14) 6 *(carried on):

A lot of these threads hating on NFTs have something against Crypto, whether they call it all a scam, or money-laundering.

They have an agenda against Crypto that they relay onto NFTs but they also don't realise you can get paid in fiat.

(13) 6:

This is all transparent, none of this is hidden, but it is also taken out of context!

99% of sales are flat payments that you can INSTANTLY withdraw to real fiat if you wanted to whenever you want. You can also adjust the price if you want it to be higher or lower.

(12) 5:

Something that you can't believe again. These are collectors ~, real people! How do you know that they are buying the piece for monetary value only?

...if you haven't even spoken to them before. Not a real conversation. Collectors are ALL different.

(11) 4:

The platforms are also a business. You can't control how someone else is feeling, it is just a form of attraction for outsiders, this is a [YOU] problem if you are manipulated by public information.

"Do you want money?" ~ is never in the equation.

(10) 3:

This is taken out of context as it is false.

On platforms, you have to pay a "fee" which is actually called "gas" as it's on the Ethereum blockchain. This money is not going to the creators of the platform.

And if you exclude that fee, you aren't losing money...

(9) 2 *(carried on):

...I also talk to many collectors who do the same / launch initiatives to further the exposure to many artists. However, collectors do not have unlimited money so they have to part w/ pieces sometimes, and some people will also buy to flip ~ don't mix them.

(8) 2:

The same point as above, it's absurd to think that these people know these collectors; they are the same people looking at the "stats" on the news to come to this conclusion.

As a collector, I buy MANY pieces just for the art and to support the artist...

(7) 1:

These are just random percentages relayed onto an infographic to make it look like a ponzi scheme.

There are hundreds of thousands of people in this market and tens of thousands of collectors. It's absurd to try put a statistic w/ out any real facts.

(6) I can nit-pick on many more things but I will explain how a majority of this thread alongside the infographics are either manipulated information + in the wrong context.

Starting from the top point ~ all the way to the bottom.

(5)

5 ‚ûù "Not all are there to make instant money"

6 ‚ûù "Imagine having a salary in CryptoCurrency"

7 ‚ûù "The problem with 'supporting friends' inside the platform"

8 ‚ûù "Promises of high returns in a short time period"

9 ‚ûù "Buy-in required"

10 ‚ûù "Emphasis on recruiting"

(4) 

1 ‚ûù Random percentages on the first graphic to display how much people are making "money" on it.

2 ‚ûù "No real art collectors in the market"

3 ‚ûù "One person has to lose money for another to make money"

4 ‚ûù "The platforms are specifically built to create that feeling"

(3) Read here for an accurate description of what a Ponzi Scheme is:
https://t.co/R6oEBGctLJ

(2) A lot of the information in this thread is using a false narrative of the market being a 'ponzi scheme', using some real information.

Manipulated information.

This is a long thread, retweet above to bring some exposure to it...

(1) A lot of gullible people falling for this.

Some of my thoughts as an artist/collector in the scene üó£Ô∏è

A long thread, retweet to share üëá: https://t.co/hwE4N7WsNT
Sharing this excellent and informative infographic made by @cabeza_patata, you can find the original post on their Instagram by the same name (1/4) https://t.co/E0PwS6fQ5f
